thread.title: UKIP leave Devon with a £500,000 bonus

author: Tina Crowson
title: UKIP leave Devon with a £500,000 bonus
text:
UKIP leave Devon with a £500,000 bonus The conference proves a welcome late summer boost for the English Riviera Share   Share 
Devon is basking in some late summer publicity sunshine as the nation’s media beat a path to UKIP’s annual conference in Torquay. 
And the English Riviera is glowing with an autumnal boost to its wallet from the spending by some 800 delegates during their two days in the resort, said to be worth around £500,000. 
This is the fourth time UKIP has held a conference in Torquay , and its second national main conference. But this time interest was high as the party elected a new leader after their Brexit referendum success followed by an apparent falling out of favour with the electorate. Henry Bolton beat off competition from six others to become UKIP’s fifth leader in 11 months. New leader Henry Bolton addressing the conference (Image: Tina Crowson) 
The one person noticeable by his absence from Torquay was former leader Nigel Farage. 
Henry Bolton told his supporters the party had to prove it was still credible, that it was a party of national government. 
"We are a party of leaders, we led on the referendum, we led on Brexit and we will lead the future of Britain," he said. 
Four time medal winner Mark Ormrod and his amazing story - back from among the dead in Afghanistan 
The party still stirs strong feelings and not just among its supporters as shown when a group of anti-racist and anti-fascists held demos outside the conference protesting against Dr Hugh Bronson, a British-German representative of the nationalist, anti-Islam Alternative for Germany party. 
Mr Bolton told delegates Britain should introduce a points system to control immigration numbers. Video Loading   
“Housing and communities are being overwhelmed, it is harming our own culture, traditions and way of life," he said. “We must demand that our own concerns about our own British culture are heard and that that feeds into our policy on immigration.” 
Simon Jolly, managing director of the Riviera International Conference Centre said the demonstration had been ‘low key’. Read More 
“It was very peaceful. There were two police liaison officers on site to keep an eye on proceedings but they weren’t called in to deal with any incidents,” he said. 
“The feedback I have had from the organisers is that it has been fantastic.” 
He said the conference was a ‘huge boost’ for the Bay and they estimated the conference had brought some £500,000 into the resort over its two days. 
That follows the success of the Young Farmers conference in the spring which attracted some 5,000 delegates and ahead of the Rotary Club of Great Britain and Ireland national conference next spring expected to attract 1,000 delegates over three nights boosting the resort by some £750,000. Read More 
The centre has has had a good season, helped by the wet August weather, which saw it break its record for the number of swimmers at 1,700. Two of the cuddlier UKIP delegates (Image: Tina Crowson) 
Mr Jolly said: “We were ahead of budget before August. It’s fortunate for us when the weather is bad but whether it is good for the resort as a whole to have a very wet week in August is another matter. ”
